description: From Middle English jasper, jaspre, from Old French jaspre, a variant of jaspe (modern French jaspe), from Latin iaspis, from Ancient Greek ἴασπις (íaspis).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Any bright-coloured kind of chalcedony apart from cornelian.
An opaque, impure variety of quartz, of red, yellow, and other dull colors, breaking conchoidally with a smooth surface.

verbs.description: jasper (third-person singular simple present jaspers, present participle jaspering, simple past and past participle jaspered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To decorate with, or as if with, jasper.

description: From the male personal name Jasper.

entries.meaning: (UK, West Country, Somerset, colloquial) A wasp.
(US, slang) A person, a guy, especially seen as naïve or simple.
examples: And list'nin to some big out-a-town jasper / Hearin' him tell about horse-race gamblin' / Not a wholesome trottin' race, no!
